DOCNAME: CASE OF PROVIDE S.R.L. v. ITALY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 13;Remainder inadmissible;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - domestic and Convention proceedings
JUDGES: Antonella Mularoni;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Luigi Ferrari Bravo;Mindia Ugrekhelidze;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a company governed by NORP law with its registered office in ORG di Sopra ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company brought proceedings against ORG and the I. company in ORG ( ORG ) ORG , seeking damages for the harm sustained in a road traffic accident , which the applicant company assessed at MONEY ( ( ITL ) – CARDINAL.CARDINAL euros ( ORG ) ) .

CARDINAL . Preparation of the case for hearing began on DATE . On DATE the applicant company requested an adjournment and on DATE it filed pleadings . Of the CARDINAL hearings scheduled DATE and DATE , CARDINAL involved the examination of witnesses and the parties , CARDINAL was adjourned at the applicant company 's request and the last was adjourned of the court 's own motion . On DATE the defendants requested an expert inquiry and the ORG reserved its decision . By an order made in camera on DATE the court rejected the request . On DATE and DATE the parties made their submissions . On DATE judgment was reserved .
CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE , the text of which was deposited with the registry on CARDINAL DATE , ORG upheld the applicant company 's claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company brought an action in ORG under PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , known as the “ Pinto Act ” , complaining that the length of the proceedings described above had been excessive and seeking just satisfaction for the non - pecuniary damage sustained .

CARDINAL . By decision of DATE , the text of which was deposited with the registry on DATE , ORG found that a reasonable time had been exceeded but dismissed the claim for compensation since the applicant company had failed to prove that it had sustained any damage .
In respect of pecuniary damage , ORG observed that the applicant company had not claimed to have sustained any such harm and that , accordingly , no sum could be awarded under that head .

As to non - pecuniary damage , ORG asserted that , although legal entities could sustain damage of that nature as a result of unreasonably lengthy proceedings , such damage could exist only where certain types of loss had been incurred and , in order to be quantified , required specific proof which had not been supplied in this case .
ORG ordered the applicant company to pay ORG ( EUR CARDINAL ) for the costs of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicant company appealed on points of law , contending that once it had been found that a reasonable time had been exceeded , legal entities were not required to adduce proof of damage which clearly gave rise in itself ( in re ipsa ) to loss .
CARDINAL . NORP By judgment of DATE , the text of which was deposited with the registry on DATE , ORG dismissed the appeal and ordered that the costs be shared between the parties .

According to ORG , LAW did not recognise any damage arising in re ipsa but required that proof be provided in accordance with LAW . Such an approach , moreover , was consistent with the ORG 's case - law under LAW .
CARDINAL . NORP By letter of DATE the applicant company informed ORG outcome of the domestic proceedings and requested it to resume the examination of its application .
CARDINAL . The relevant domestic law and practice are set out in PERSON v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no .. CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL-V ) .
